value.headline: The all-in-one way to build websites
value.body: Hit the ground running with primo's ready-to-use components or start from scratch. Manage your content yourself or invite collaborators. Host your site anywhere and never sweat a security update again.

fields.label: Body
fields.value: Hit the ground running with primo's ready-to-use components or start from scratch. Manage your content yourself or invite collaborators. Host your site anywhere and never sweat a security update again.

value.title: Component-Driven IDE
value.subtitle: Use primo's built-in components out of the box or modify them right from your browser. Build your own library using TailwindCSS and use your components across websites.

fields.label: Heading
fields.value: Frequently Asked Questions

fields.label: Subheading
fields.value: Ut ornare lectus sit amet est placerat in egestas erat. Ut sem nulla pharetra diam sit amet nisl.

value.title: What's this good for?
value.body: primo lets you build fast, secure, scalable websites which can be edited by anyone. Similar to WordPress, you can use pre-built components to get started quickly. But unlike WordPress, themes and components can be easily modified right from your browser. You'll never again say to yourself "this would be easier if I could just get to the code".

value.title: What isn't this good for?
value.body: At the moment, primo works best with websites consisting of fewer than thirty pages and simple data and media demands. There are much better options out there meant for creating large, data-heavy sites (NextJS, Hugo, ElderJS).

value.title: Can I use primo's IDE with another CMS?
value.body: Not yet, but we're working on data integrations so you can use any other CMS (WordPress, Google Sheets, etc.) to populate your components and pages with data.

value.title: Can I use primo's CMS with another IDE/framework?
value.body: Not yet, but we're planning on making it possible to edit your site locally (e.g. i.e. in VSCode) to achieve higher-level functionality.

value.title: Is this under active development?
value.body: Primo is being worked on full-time by a small bootstrapped team. We've been working on it for a year and a half and have enough runway to sustain ourselves until at least 2022.

value.html:
Why primo?

There are plenty of options today for people to build websites - whether you can code or not. If you can’t code, you can take your pick of site builders (find one by watching any YouTube ad). If you can code, then the world really opens up for you - static site generators, headless CMSs, server-side frameworks. But one of the few options which is both end-user friendly while being capable of custom development (i.e. approachable and powerful) is WordPress. For the last two decades, WordPress has allowed people to start building quickly with pre-built components while providing the ability to build custom themes and even entire applications.

But after 20 years, WordPress leaves a lot to be desired. Each WordPress site needs a heavy stack. It’s rife with security vulnerability and requires constant upkeep. The sites load slowly without optimization and can go down if they get enough traffic (not to mention hosting fees). But the worst offense to WordPress’ developer users may be its clear evolution to being a site-builder. Over time, WordPress has evolved into a tool which would sooner be used to replace a developer than make their life easier.

In contrast, primo is built with developers in mind. It skyrockets developer productivity by leveraging the latest in serverless tech and streamlining development so code changes can be deployed in seconds and content editors can focus on content. It’s approachable by developers of any skill level thanks to the built-in IDE and simple Handlebars templating, and offers content editors arguably the easiest CMS in existence.

On each update, primo builds a slim static site out to a Github repo under your account. You can host it anywhere, but the easiest place to host it is on Vercel or Netlify, since you can set your site up to publish each new update which arrives to the repo. Once your site’s hosted, you’ll never have to think about it again if you don’t want to. No critical security updates, no content editors accidentally breaking the site, no worn out servers squeezing out the same page over and over again, no worries.
Get started

value.html:
The people behind primo

Primo has been under active development for just over a year and half by a fully remote, bootstrapped team that loves open source and building technology that empowers people.

value.html:
Future features and works in progress

Even though primo's already super useful, there's a lot of room to grow - here's what's coming up on the docket. If any of these excite you and you'd like to help out, feel free to grab a feature or join the Discord to see how you can help.

  • Load data from an API - Use primo with other CMSs/data sources

  • Server-side Rendering - Necessary for keeping external data up to date

  • Desktop app - Build primo sites from your desktop (faster & offline)

  • Tailwind Intellisense - Create components using Tailwind Intellisense in the IDE

  • Svelte Component Type - Create Svelte components alongside HTML/CSS/JS components

  • Service Workers - Create service workers from within primo to enable multithreading and offline functionality

  • Custom Sections - Build reusable page sections by defining each columns tags and classes

  • Offline Support

If you'd like to help bring any of these ideas to life (or you have another one in mind), join our Discord to see how you can help out.

value.html:
How it works

Primo.af is a hosted service - this makes it easier to get started and use.

It’s a web application which lets you build and manage your websites, but not host them. This is part of why we’re able to offer a generous free tier without bleeding money (it actually costs us close to nothing to offer the free tier).

When you create a website, primo automatically builds a repo under your Github account and stores your entire site inside of a single file called `primo.json`. It also builds your website out to the same repository. This is another reason primo can remain free, because it leverages Github as a backbone for storing your data, website, and even your images.

Once you’ve built your website out to your repository, it’s straightforward and also free to put it up on the internet for everyone to see.

value.html:
How they work:

  • Wordpress is server-side PHP application that needs to be installed on an Apache server, alongside a SQLite database, with NGINX and whatnot. If you want a second website, you have to do that all over again on another server. It is also offered as a service by its creator, Automattic, for x dollars a month per site. 

  • Primo is a client-side Svelte application that can be served on any static host, even a Dropbox folder. It uses a GitHub repository that both stores a JSON file as a database and where it keeps, tracks, and updates the static website files. A single primo server can host a theoretically unlimited number of websites. It is available as a service on primo.so for free, for an unlimited number of websites, with additional features available for a monthly price. 


What they do:

  • By default, a WordPress site has a theme applied, and you can get more themes for free at wordpress.org. WordPress lets you create posts as well as pages, write your content in the editor with some flexibility, and quickly publish or draft your changes to each site. There is a massive online market for additional themes or functionality, letting you turn your site into just about anything. You can also invite other people to edit the website. 

  • Primo offers a few free choices for themes, as well as paid themes. All themes in primo are modular and compatible, meaning that every website built or migrated to primo can have its pieces used across any other website on primo (with changes depending on their context). Primo sites are developed in a cloud IDE (meaning the browser), similar to sites like codesandbox and replit. It requires no setup and comes with TailwindCSS, ES Modules, and instant preview, among other useful development features to create components. Components are edited from forms in isolation, and copy content is edited on the frontend (with formatting available from the toolbar or using auto-converting Markdown). When changes to a primo site are saved, primo builds a save file (primo.json) to a connected Github repo. When the site changed are published, it builds a static site out to the same repo, from which it can be deployed to any given host. 


Which one’s better:

  • WordPress has been around for a long time, it’s had millions of users, thousands of contributors, and today serves a third of the websites on the internet. People and organizations of all sizes have depended on it for a long time, even the White House. With the recent Gutenberg editor, WordPress is user friendly enough to be considered a site builder. 

  • Primo’s foundation is built on the best of modern open source technologies. It doesn’t yet include nearly the subset of features of WordPress, but because it’s focused on smaller website instead of serving every need, it works very well for many use cases. Where WordPress has taken gone the way of site builders to cater directly to content editors, primo enables content editors by enabling developers. 


Who they’re good for:

  • Wordpress is good for large websites (50+ pages) with many data types and posts. It’s also good if you’re not a developer, or if you’re a WordPress developer with a good workflow for building from scratch, reusing components, and tracking your site with Git. It’s good if you have a lot of collaborators, and are frequently updating content. It’s good if you need a lot of pre-built functionality (as long as those plugins aren’t just something you could easily do with some code). 

  • Primo is good for smaller websites (less than 30 pages) with simply structured data. It’s good for one to a few collaborators. It has an ideal writing experience, and a simple, understandable interface for editing components. It’s good if you have more than one site, because you don’t have to think about them unless you want to. It’s good if you’re a developer (even a novice), because you can always unlock more functionality at a moment’s notice. It’s good if you like reusing components across sites.

WordPress vs primo

How they work

  • Wordpress is server-side PHP application that needs to be installed on an Apache server, alongside a SQLite database, with NGINX and whatnot. If you want a second website, you have to do that all over again on another server. It is also offered as a service by its creator, Automattic, for x dollars a month per site. 

  • Primo is a client-side Svelte application that can be served on any static host, even a Dropbox folder. It doesn’t yet include nearly the subset of features of WordPress, but because it’s focused on smaller website instead of serving every need, it works very well for many use cases. It’s good if you need a lot of pre-built functionality (as long as those plugins aren’t just something you could easily do with some code).

It’s good if you’re a developer (even a novice), because you can always unlock more functionality at a moment’s notice. It’s good if you like reusing components across sites.

value.html:
Blog

Proprietary no-code site builders make small, new, and one-off websites easier to build because they offer ready-to-use components, a simple way to build a website, and a relatively easy content editing experience - all without touching a line of code. But as developers, we know that “no-code” is a bug, not a feature.

value.html:
Why primo?

All-in-One

primo puts every part of your website within arm’s reach, making is easier to get started and simpler to deploy code and content updates. Whether you’re building from scratch or starting with pre-built components, you can immediately start editing code in the built-in IDE. And when you build a component, you can immediately start using it across all your sites. Besides a bunch of other benefits, this approach also enables the second half of primo’s strategy for productivity.

Component-driven

According to componentdriven.org, “Components are standardized, interchangeable building blocks of UIs. They encapsulate the appearance and function of UI pieces. Think LEGO bricks. LEGOs can be used to build everything from castles to spaceships; components can be taken apart and used to create new features”. primo makes this possible by integrating every part of a website - from the structure to the content - into modular components called Blocks. Websites in primo usually get edited one block at a time, but they can also be modified at the page and site level. So no matter what you want to edit or update on your site, whether you want to edit its code or its content, every change can be deployed in moments by navigating to a component and clicking ‘edit’. And maybe the biggest benefit is that, because every primo site is modular, every Block in primo can [usually] be seamlessly copied between all your sites.

Developer-friendly

Developers often have to choose between getting started quickly (but being locked) in and getting started slowly but being able to grow and scale. With primo, you don’t have to make that decision. You can both get started quickly by using the growing list of pre-built themes and components, and also have direct access to their code to modify them and build new components from scratch.

Code changes are always one toggle switch away. There’s no need to clone or bundle, your environment is always ready to go with instant previews, TailwindCSS, and JS modules. All you need to get started is a mobile or desktop browser.
Get started
